title: TNNT: The Named Entity Recognition Toolkit

sentences.text: Extraction of categorised named entities from text is a complex task given the availability of a variety of Named Entity Recognition (NER) models and the unstructured information encoded in different source document formats.
Processing the documents to extract text, identifying suitable NER models for a task, and obtaining statistical information is important in data analysis to make informed decisions.

This paper presents1 TNNT, a toolkit that automates the extraction of categorised named entities from unstructured information encoded in source documents, using diverse state-of-the-art (SOTA) Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools and NER models.

TNNT integrates 21 different NER models as part of a Knowledge Graph Construction Pipeline (KGCP) that takes a document set as input and processes it based on the defined settings, applying the selected blocks of NER models to output the results.
The toolkit generates all results with an integrated summary of the extracted entities, enabling enhanced data analysis to support the KGCP, and also, to aid further NLP tasks.
NER is a major component in NLP systems to extract information from unstructured text.
Recent advances in deep learning and NLP have resulted in the availability of a large number of NER tools and models for use which have enabled NER of different categories from text.

However, given the existence of a wide range of document formats, extracting information is difficult considering the preprocessing required prior to using NER tools and the challenge of identifying which models to use.

It is desirable to have a system that can provide (1) a uniform processing pipeline of different document formats, (2) easy selection of different NLP-NER models or tools, (3) an integrated summary of the entities identified by the models, and (4) basic functionalities to access the results; in order to enhance data analysis with accurate decisions and to provide a thorough overview of the data used.
This paper introduces TNNT2 .

Its main goal is to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in the source documents, using a wide range of recent SOTA NLP-NER tools and models.

TNNT is integrated with the “Metadata Extractor & Loader" (MEL) [10], which enables extraction of metadata and content-based information from various file formats such as .pdf, .docx, .xlsx, .msg, .csv, .txt, and .zip.
We have brought together the existing SOTA NER models and NLP tools under one toolkit, enabling effortless NER analysis for unstructured content-based information.

The motivations of the toolkit are: (1) to be able to easily pre-process documents for NER analysis, (2) to be able to easily use documents with different formats for NER analysis, (3) to hide usage variations across NER models and NLP tools, and bring them under one uniform pipeline, and (4) to provide a framework for analysing results from different NER models and NLP tools.

Having several SOTA models under one umbrella provides many benefits such as their easy execution and comparison, and, most interestingly, it can help to identify the most suited block of NER models for a specific task or input domain.
There are a wide range of libraries, such as NLTK [7], spaCy3, Stanford NER [8], Stanza [9], and Flair [1], that provide models facilitating NER.
To the best of our knowledge, there is no toolkit or system that unifies under one uniform pipeline several SOTA tools and models for NER: TNNT fills this void.
TNNT integrates 21 different NER models from 9 SOTA NLP tools (Table 1).
Some of these models are based on rule-based and statistical approaches whereas others are based on deep learning techniques4 .
These 21 models can identify up to 18 categories (Table 2) of named entities in text.
The system is capable of processing different models sequentially based on the input settings (processing blocks) defined by the user.
All textual content extracted by MEL is processable for TNNT with a hybrid processing data flow, either from/to a document store or via direct processing from the file system.
For data analysis tasks, TNNT keeps general statistics of the models and generates an integrated summary of all the identified entities.
The results are JSON files (one for each processed source document) with the list of models, categories, and identified entities.
For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves a set of information specific to the entity .

A built-in RESTful API provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate the NER results by performing other NLP tasks, such as Part-Of-Speech (POS) tagging, dependency parsing, and co-reference resolution.
This comprehensive information facilitates the apprehension of the models as well the data used for NLP tasks in general and, in particular, for tasks associated with knowledge building.
TNNT was designed to systematically apply various NER models to analyse textual content extracted via MEL.
Whereas the latter implements several data extraction operations, the former provides a modular and extensible framework for NER analysis using multiple models and NLP tools.
In a nutshell, TNNT is fully integrated with MEL as shown in Figure 1.
The toolkit's processing model is depicted in Figure 2.

The first two blocks are orchestrated by MEL which establishes how TNNT will process a block sequence of NER models to apply over the input dataset (either from a document store or from a direct document processing immediately after the metadata extraction task).
TNNT's inner architecture is composed of a pre-processing module and one distinct module for each implemented NLP-NER tool and models.
Based on the input document formats (file extensions), the pre-processing module takes the extracted text data by MEL and cleans/prepares it for the NER analysis task.
The core analysis task on the input data is sequentially performed for all the selected NER models.
TNNT's modular design enables a smooth selection and processing mechanism of the NER models.
For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves its context information, and start/end indices in the document text.
Furthermore, it provides statistics of the entities identified by each model for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task.
Table 3 gives an overview of the results obtained using some of the models for two publicly available datasets: CONLL 20036 and NIST IE-ER7 .
The toolkit has a set of comprehensive configuration files that specify all the required details and processing parameters for each implemented NLP tool and NER model.
Users can experiment with various models by simply defining the desired settings.

TNNT's RESTful API refines and improves the NER results by adding more processing layers of abstraction to perform several useful operations, such as POS tagging, dependency parsing, coreference resolution, aggregations, descriptive stats, and browsing capabilities, as shown in Figure 3.
This module allows users to smoothly traverse and retrieve the NER results.
Its specifications and usage can be found at the project's w3id URI.
TNNT provides a simple mechanism and uniform pipeline to extract categorised named entities from unstructured data using a diverse range of SOTA NLP tools and NER models.
This tool is still in its early stages of development.
It has been tested using thousands of different document formats and datasets as part of the “Australian Government Records Interoperability Framework" (AGRIF) project [4].

There are ongoing plans to integrate more NLP-NER tools and models into the architecture along with continuing evolving the RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results, in order to support KGCP tasks.

The major contributions of this toolkit are: (1) the ability to process different source document formats for NER; (2) the availability of 21 different SOTA NER models integrated into one system, enabling easy selection of models for NER; (3) the provision of an integrated summary of the results from different models; and (4) a RESTful API that enables easy access to NLP tasks that enrich the NER results from the models.

summary:
Extraction of categorised named entities from text is a complex task given the availability of a variety of Named Entity Recognition (NER) models and the unstructured information encoded in different source document formats. Processing the documents to extract text, identifying suitable NER models for a task, and obtaining statistical information is important in data analysis to make informed decisions. This paper presents1 TNNT, a toolkit that automates the extraction of categorised named entities from unstructured information encoded in source documents, using diverse state-of-the-art (SOTA) Natural Language Processing (NLP) tools and NER models. TNNT integrates 21 different NER models as part of a Knowledge Graph Construction Pipeline (KGCP) that takes a document set as input and processes it based on the defined settings, applying the selected blocks of NER models to output the results. The toolkit generates all results with an integrated summary of the extracted entities, enabling enhanced data analysis to support the KGCP, and also, to aid further NLP tasks.

NER is a major component in NLP systems to extract information from unstructured text. Recent advances in deep learning and NLP have resulted in the availability of a large number of NER tools and models for use which have enabled NER of different categories from text. However, given the existence of a wide range of document formats, extracting information is difficult considering the preprocessing required prior to using NER tools and the challenge of identifying which models to use. It is desirable to have a system that can provide (1) a uniform processing pipeline of different document formats, (2) easy selection of different NLP-NER models or tools, (3) an integrated summary of the entities identified by the models, and (4) basic functionalities to access the results; in order to enhance data analysis with accurate decisions and to provide a thorough overview of the data used.

This paper introduces TNNT2 . Its main goal is to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in the source documents, using a wide range of recent SOTA NLP-NER tools and models. TNNT is integrated with the “Metadata Extractor & Loader" (MEL) [10], which enables extraction of metadata and content-based information from various file formats such as .pdf, .docx, .xlsx, .msg, .csv, .txt, and .zip. We have brought together the existing SOTA NER models and NLP tools under one toolkit, enabling effortless NER analysis for unstructured content-based information. The motivations of the toolkit are: (1) to be able to easily pre-process documents for NER analysis, (2) to be able to easily use documents with different formats for NER analysis, (3) to hide usage variations across NER models and NLP tools, and bring them under one uniform pipeline, and (4) to provide a framework for analysing results from different NER models and NLP tools. Having several SOTA models under one umbrella provides many benefits such as their easy execution and comparison, and, most interestingly, it can help to identify the most suited block of NER models for a specific task or input domain.

There are a wide range of libraries, such as NLTK [7], spaCy3, Stanford NER [8], Stanza [9], and Flair [1], that provide models facilitating NER. To the best of our knowledge, there is no toolkit or system that unifies under one uniform pipeline several SOTA tools and models for NER: TNNT fills this void.

TNNT integrates 21 different NER models from 9 SOTA NLP tools (Table 1). Some of these models are based on rule-based and statistical approaches whereas others are based on deep learning techniques4 . These 21 models can identify up to 18 categories (Table 2) of named entities in text. The system is capable of processing different models sequentially based on the input settings (processing blocks) defined by the user. All textual content extracted by MEL is processable for TNNT with a hybrid processing data flow, either from/to a document store or via direct processing from the file system.

For data analysis tasks, TNNT keeps general statistics of the models and generates an integrated summary of all the identified entities. The results are JSON files (one for each processed source document) with the list of models, categories, and identified entities. For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves a set of information specific to the entity . A built-in RESTful API provides various features to access, expand, complement, and co-relate the NER results by performing other NLP tasks, such as Part-Of-Speech (POS) tagging, dependency parsing, and co-reference resolution. This comprehensive information facilitates the apprehension of the models as well the data used for NLP tasks in general and, in particular, for tasks associated with knowledge building.

TNNT was designed to systematically apply various NER models to analyse textual content extracted via MEL. Whereas the latter implements several data extraction operations, the former provides a modular and extensible framework for NER analysis using multiple models and NLP tools. In a nutshell, TNNT is fully integrated with MEL as shown in Figure 1. The toolkit's processing model is depicted in Figure 2. The first two blocks are orchestrated by MEL which establishes how TNNT will process a block sequence of NER models to apply over the input dataset (either from a document store or from a direct document processing immediately after the metadata extraction task).

TNNT's inner architecture is composed of a pre-processing module and one distinct module for each implemented NLP-NER tool and models. Based on the input document formats (file extensions), the pre-processing module takes the extracted text data by MEL and cleans/prepares it for the NER analysis task. The core analysis task on the input data is sequentially performed for all the selected NER models. TNNT's modular design enables a smooth selection and processing mechanism of the NER models. For each recognised entity, the toolkit retrieves its context information, and start/end indices in the document text. Furthermore, it provides statistics of the entities identified by each model for respective categories along with the start/end timestamps and the duration taken by the models to run the NER task. Table 3 gives an overview of the results obtained using some of the models for two publicly available datasets: CONLL 20036 and NIST IE-ER7 . The toolkit has a set of comprehensive configuration files that specify all the required details and processing parameters for each implemented NLP tool and NER model. Users can experiment with various models by simply defining the desired settings.

TNNT's RESTful API refines and improves the NER results by adding more processing layers of abstraction to perform several useful operations, such as POS tagging, dependency parsing, coreference resolution, aggregations, descriptive stats, and browsing capabilities, as shown in Figure 3. This module allows users to smoothly traverse and retrieve the NER results. Its specifications and usage can be found at the project's w3id URI.

TNNT provides a simple mechanism and uniform pipeline to extract categorised named entities from unstructured data using a diverse range of SOTA NLP tools and NER models. This tool is still in its early stages of development. It has been tested using thousands of different document formats and datasets as part of the “Australian Government Records Interoperability Framework" (AGRIF) project [4]. There are ongoing plans to integrate more NLP-NER tools and models into the architecture along with continuing evolving the RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results, in order to support KGCP tasks. The major contributions of this toolkit are: (1) the ability to process different source document formats for NER; (2) the availability of 21 different SOTA NER models integrated into one system, enabling easy selection of models for NER; (3) the provision of an integrated summary of the results from different models; and (4) a RESTful API that enables easy access to NLP tasks that enrich the NER results from the models.

Predicate-is_important_in.label: is important in
Predicate-is_important_in.description: The predicate 'is important in' indicates a relationship where the subject plays a crucial role or has significant relevance within the context of the object. It suggests that the subject is essential, vital, or necessary for achieving some goal, making progress, or understanding something about the object.

Predicate-presents.label: presents
Predicate-presents.description: The predicate 'presents' indicates a relationship where the subject provides or offers something to someone or for some purpose. The object represents what is being presented, which can be an idea, concept, argument, evidence, or other form of information.

Predicate-automates.label: automates
Predicate-automates.description: To automate means to perform a task or process using automated systems or processes, thereby reducing human intervention and increasing efficiency. The subject (TNNT) represents an entity that performs this automation, connecting it with the object (Extraction of categorised named entities from text), which is the specific task or process being automated.

Predicate-integrates.label: integrates
Predicate-integrates.description: To integrate means to combine or unify two or more entities, concepts, or systems into a cohesive whole. This predicate indicates that the subject (TNNT) brings together and harmonizes with the object (SOTA NER models), creating a unified entity or system.

Predicate-generates.label: generates
Predicate-generates.description: Generates indicates a process where the subject produces or creates something new that has a specific relationship to the object. The connection between the subject and object lies in the fact that the generated output meets certain criteria, specifications, or expectations defined by the object.

Predicate-is_a_major_component_in.label: is a major component in
Predicate-is_a_major_component_in.description: This predicate indicates that the subject has a significant and essential role within or as part of the object. It suggests a relationship where the subject is an integral element contributing to the overall structure, function, or purpose of the object.

Predicate-provide.label: provide
Predicate-provide.description: The predicate 'provide' indicates that the subject offers or makes available something to someone or for some purpose, connecting it with the object. In this general sense, providing implies a transfer of resources, information, or services from the subject to fulfill a need or achieve an objective.

Predicate-introduces.label: introduces
Predicate-introduces.description: Introduces refers to a relationship where one entity (the subject) presents or brings forth another entity (the object), often providing an initial overview, explanation, or context for understanding. This predicate typically indicates that the subject provides a gateway or entry point into the knowledge, concept, or idea represented by the object.

Predicate-is_to_automate.label: is to automate
Predicate-is_to_automate.description: The predicate 'is to automate' indicates that a process or system aims to perform an action automatically, without human intervention. It implies a transformation of manual tasks into automated ones, potentially increasing efficiency and reducing errors.

Predicate-have_brought_together.label: have brought together
Predicate-have_brought_together.description: To gather or unite disparate entities, concepts, or resources into a single entity, concept, or resource. This predicate indicates that the subject has taken an active role in combining or integrating multiple elements to form something new.

Predicate-and.label: and
Predicate-and.description: The predicate 'and' connects two entities or concepts by indicating a relationship of conjunction, equivalence, or coexistence. It suggests that the subject and object share common characteristics, properties, or attributes, implying a sense of similarity, unity, or mutual relevance.

Predicate-under.label: under
Predicate-under.description: The predicate 'under' indicates a relationship of containment or subordination between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject is somehow included within or subordinate to the object, implying a hierarchical structure where one entity has dominance over another.

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: Indicates a state or characteristic that holds true about the subject. The predicate 'are' connects the subject and object by stating an equivalence, similarity, or identity between them.

Predicate-fills_this_void.label: fills this void
Predicate-fills_this_void.description: The predicate 'fills this void' indicates that the subject (e.g. NER tools and models) provides a solution or answers to the object's (e.g. TNNT) lack, gap, or unmet need.

Predicate-from.label: from
Predicate-from.description: The predicate 'from' indicates a relationship of origin or source between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has its roots, foundation, or starting point from the specified location, entity, or concept represented by the object.

Predicate-are_based_on.label: are based on
Predicate-are_based_on.description: The predicate 'are based on' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, some of these models) derive their foundation or principles from the object (rule-based and statistical approaches). It suggests that the subject's characteristics, methods, or underlying assumptions are rooted in or inspired by the object.

Predicate-is_capable_of_processing.label: is capable of processing
Predicate-is_capable_of_processing.description: Indicates that a subject has the ability to handle or manage an object in some way. This predicate suggests that the subject possesses the necessary skills, knowledge, or resources to process the information contained within the object.

Predicate-extracts.label: extracts
Predicate-extracts.description: The predicate 'extracts' indicates a process of obtaining or selecting specific information from a larger body of text. It implies that the subject (MEL, for example) is responsible for identifying and isolating relevant content within the object (All textual content), which can be understood as a collection of written material.

Predicate-is_processable_for.label: is processable for
Predicate-is_processable_for.description: The predicate 'is processable for' indicates that the subject has the capability or suitability to be processed according to some specific criteria or standards, which are described by the object. In general, this predicate establishes a relationship between the subject and an entity (the object) that defines how well-suited the subject is to undergo processing.

Predicate-keeps_general_statistics_of.label: keeps general statistics of
Predicate-keeps_general_statistics_of.description: The predicate 'keeps general statistics of' indicates a relationship where the subject entity collects and maintains aggregated information about the object concept. This connection implies that the subject has some level of responsibility or authority to gather, analyze, and store data related to the object.

Predicate-generates_an_integrated_summar.label: generates an integrated summary of
Predicate-generates_an_integrated_summar.description: The predicate 'generates an integrated summary of' indicates that the subject (a system or process) produces a concise and comprehensive overview of the object (information, data, or entities), integrating relevant details to convey key insights.

Predicate-retrieves.label: retrieves
Predicate-retrieves.description: The predicate 'retrieves' indicates that the subject acquires or obtains the object, often in a context where the object was previously inaccessible, unknown, or hidden. This can involve searching for, finding, collecting, or extracting information from various sources.

Predicate-facilitates_the_apprehension_o.label: facilitates the apprehension of
Predicate-facilitates_the_apprehension_o.description: The predicate 'facilitates the apprehension of' indicates that the subject provides a means or mechanism to understand or comprehend the object. It suggests that the subject makes it easier, more accessible, or clearer for someone (or something) to grasp the meaning, significance, or implications of the object.

Predicate-apply.label: apply
Predicate-apply.description: To apply means to use or put into effect a specific technique, method, or approach (object) on or with something (subject), typically resulting in a transformation, modification, or improvement of that thing.

Predicate-analyse.label: analyse
Predicate-analyse.description: To examine or investigate a subject's properties, characteristics, or relationships with its object to gain a deeper understanding of it.

Predicate-integrated_with.label: integrated with
Predicate-integrated_with.description: The predicate 'integrated with' indicates a relationship of unity or cohesion between two entities. It suggests that the subject and object are combined into a single, cohesive whole, often implying a loss of individual identity or autonomy.

Predicate-implements.label: implements
Predicate-implements.description: The predicate 'implements' indicates that the subject has created or developed a specific capability, process, or system to achieve a particular goal or function. It suggests a relationship of design, creation, or execution between the subject and object.

Predicate-is_integrated_with.label: is integrated with
Predicate-is_integrated_with.description: Indicates a relationship where two entities are combined or unified to form a new whole. This predicate suggests that the subject and object have merged their respective aspects, functions, or characteristics to create something novel.

Predicate-is_depicted_in.label: is depicted in
Predicate-is_depicted_in.description: This predicate indicates a representation or illustration of something (the subject), which is presented within another entity (the object). The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject is being visually represented, described, or portrayed in some way through the medium or format specified by the object.

Predicate-orchestrates.label: orchestrates
Predicate-orchestrates.description: To orchestrate means to carefully plan and coordinate a complex process or activity, bringing together different elements or components into a harmonious whole. In this sense, the predicate 'orchestrates' connects the subject (the entity responsible for planning) with the object (the thing being planned), indicating that the subject is actively shaping and directing the object's various parts to achieve a unified outcome.

Predicate-provides.label: provides
Predicate-provides.description: The predicate 'provides' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case MEL) offers or makes available something to someone else. The object of the sentence, in this example 'textual content', represents what is being provided by the subject.

Predicate-is_performed_for.label: is performed for
Predicate-is_performed_for.description: The predicate 'is performed for' indicates a relationship where an action or activity (subject) has been done with a specific purpose or goal in mind, which is represented by the object. In general, this predicate suggests that the subject was undertaken to achieve something specified by the object.

Predicate-performed_on.label: performed on
Predicate-performed_on.description: Indicates that an action or process was carried out with respect to a specific entity (object), which serves as its subject matter. The predicate 'performed on' establishes a relationship between the subject, typically an agent or actor, and the object, often representing data, information, or material being analyzed, processed, or manipulated.

Predicate-gives_an_overview_of.label: gives an overview of
Predicate-gives_an_overview_of.description: The predicate 'gives an overview of' indicates a relationship where the subject provides a concise summary or introduction to the object, which typically represents a larger body of information. The connection between the subject and object is one of summarization or presentation, implying that the subject has condensed or organized the content described by the object into a more digestible form.

Predicate-is_a_dataset_used_in.label: is a dataset used in
Predicate-is_a_dataset_used_in.description: This predicate indicates that the subject (a specific dataset or collection of data) has been utilized or employed for some purpose within the context described by the object. The relationship between the subject and object suggests a connection where the dataset plays a role in achieving, illustrating, or supporting the information presented.

Predicate-is_another_dataset_used_in.label: is another dataset used in
Predicate-is_another_dataset_used_in.description: This predicate indicates a relationship between a subject (a specific dataset or entity) and an object (another dataset), suggesting that the former is utilized or incorporated within the latter. The connection implies a functional dependency, where the subject's data or characteristics are used in some capacity to support or inform the object.

Predicate-has.label: has
Predicate-has.description: Indicates a state of possession or association between the subject and object. The predicate 'has' suggests that the subject possesses, contains, or is characterized by the object.

Predicate-specify.label: specify
Predicate-specify.description: To specify means to clearly define or identify something by providing specific information about its characteristics, properties, or requirements. It implies a level of precision and detail that helps to distinguish the subject from others or clarify its intended purpose.

Predicate-experiment_with.label: experiment with
Predicate-experiment_with.description: To engage in a process of testing or trying out different approaches, methods, or ideas to gain insight, understand behavior, or evaluate performance. The subject (Users) applies their skills and knowledge to investigate or explore the object (Some of these models), often with the goal of refining, improving, or optimizing them.

Predicate-define.label: define
Predicate-define.description: To specify or clarify the meaning of something by providing a clear and concise explanation, typically involving the identification of essential characteristics, properties, or features. This predicate connects the subject to the object by establishing a precise understanding of what the subject represents or encompasses.

Predicate-refines.label: refines
Predicate-refines.description: To refine something means to make it more precise or accurate by removing impurities, errors, or ambiguities. In this context, the subject (TNNT's RESTful API) improves or enhances the object (the NER results), likely through some process of filtering, correcting, or reorganizing the data.

Predicate-improves.label: improves
Predicate-improves.description: The predicate 'improves' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object, suggesting that the subject has a positive impact on or enhances the quality of the object. In general, it implies an improvement in some aspect or characteristic of the object.

Predicate-add.label: add
Predicate-add.description: The predicate 'add' indicates a process of combining or incorporating new elements into an existing structure, system, or concept. It suggests that the subject (TNNT's RESTful API) is being augmented with additional components, features, or layers to enhance its capabilities or functionality.

Predicate-refines_and_improves.label: refines and improves
Predicate-refines_and_improves.description: The predicate 'refines and improves' indicates a process of enhancing or optimizing the quality, accuracy, or effectiveness of something (the object), typically through the application of expertise, knowledge, or techniques by someone or something (the subject).

Predicate-allows.label: allows
Predicate-allows.description: The predicate 'allows' indicates a permission or authorization for the subject to perform an action or access something related to the object. It implies that the subject has the capability or right to engage with, utilize, or interact with the object in some way.

Predicate-traverse_and_retrieve.label: traverse and retrieve
Predicate-traverse_and_retrieve.description: To traverse and retrieve means to navigate through or move across a given space (physical or conceptual), gathering or collecting specific information or data as one goes. This predicate connects the subject, which initiates the traversal, with the object, which represents the target of the retrieval process.

Predicate-can_be_found_at.label: can be found at
Predicate-can_be_found_at.description: Indicates that information about or related to the subject can be accessed through a specific location or resource denoted by the object. This predicate establishes a connection between the subject and the object, suggesting that the latter serves as a gateway or reference point for obtaining more details about the former.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship of utilization or employment, where the subject (TNNT) leverages or exploits the object (state-of-the-art NLP tools and NER models) to achieve some purpose or goal. This connection implies that the subject relies on, benefits from, or makes use of the object's capabilities, features, or resources.

Predicate-integrate.label: integrate
Predicate-integrate.description: To combine or unify two entities (subject and object), typically involving a process of merging, unifying, or bringing together distinct components to form a cohesive whole. This predicate suggests an action that harmonizes disparate elements into a single entity.

Predicate-evolve.label: evolve
Predicate-evolve.description: To evolve means to undergo a process of gradual and continuous change or development, often resulting in increased complexity, sophistication, or refinement. The predicate 'evolve' connects the subject (the entity undergoing change) with the object (the aspect or feature being modified), indicating that the subject is transforming into something new or improved.

Predicate-support.label: support
Predicate-support.description: The predicate 'support' indicates a relationship where the subject provides resources, backing, or justification for the object. This connection implies that the subject enables, facilitates, or validates the existence or success of the object.

Predicate-offers.label: offers
Predicate-offers.description: The predicate 'offers' indicates a relationship where the subject provides or presents something to someone else, often with the intention of sharing knowledge, resources, or expertise. The object represents what is being offered, which can be an idea, a service, a product, or even a solution to a problem.

Predicate-continues_evolving_its_RESTful.label: continues evolving its RESTful API with complementary NLP tasks to enrich the NER results in order to support
Predicate-continues_evolving_its_RESTful.description: This predicate describes an ongoing process of refining and enhancing a subject's (typically AI-related) capabilities by continuously updating its RESTful API with new Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks, which in turn improve Named Entity Recognition (NER) results to support specific knowledge graph construction or processing tasks.

Predicate-automates_extraction_using.label: automates extraction using
Predicate-automates_extraction_using.description: The predicate 'automates extraction using' indicates that the subject (an entity or process) employs a specific method, technique, or tool to extract information from something. The object specifies what this method involves, such as a particular technology, approach, or set of tools.

Predicate-automates_the_extraction.label: automates the extraction
Predicate-automates_the_extraction.description: The predicate 'automates the extraction' indicates that the subject takes action to extract or obtain information from a source (the object), streamlining and simplifying the process.

Predicate-enables.label: enables
Predicate-enables.description: The predicate 'enables' indicates that the subject has the capability or authority to facilitate or make possible the occurrence of the object, which represents a state, action, or ability. In general, it suggests a causal relationship where the subject's presence or involvement allows for the realization or achievement of the object.

Predicate-are_integrated_into.label: are integrated into
Predicate-are_integrated_into.description: Indicates that the subject's components or aspects are combined with or merged into the object to form a unified whole. This predicate suggests a process of incorporation, assimilation, or synthesis where distinct elements become part of a larger system.

Predicate-are_used_to_analyze.label: are used to analyze
Predicate-are_used_to_analyze.description: This predicate indicates a purpose or function that connects the subject (models) with an object (input data), suggesting that the subject's primary role is to examine, inspect, or investigate the object in order to gain insights, identify patterns, or draw conclusions.

Predicate-utilize.label: utilize
Predicate-utilize.description: To utilize means to make use of or take advantage of something, such as a resource, technology, or method. It implies that the subject has chosen to employ or leverage the object for some purpose or benefit.

Predicate-was_motivated_by.label: was motivated by
Predicate-was_motivated_by.description: Indicates that a subject's actions or decisions were driven by an underlying reason, goal, or objective. The predicate connects the subject to its motivation, implying a causal relationship between the two.

Predicate-requires.label: requires
Predicate-requires.description: The predicate 'requires' indicates a necessary condition or prerequisite for something to happen. It implies that the subject needs or demands the object in order to fulfill its purpose, achieve its goal, or operate effectively.

Predicate-fills.label: fills
Predicate-fills.description: Indicates that something (the subject) provides or satisfies a need, gap, or absence described by the object. The predicate 'fills' implies a sense of completion, fulfillment, or satisfaction.

Predicate-is_motivated_by.label: is motivated by
Predicate-is_motivated_by.description: The predicate 'is motivated by' indicates a causal relationship between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject's behavior or actions are driven by the underlying reasons, goals, or principles represented by the object.

Predicate-was_developed_to_automate.label: was developed to automate
Predicate-was_developed_to_automate.description: This predicate indicates that a system or process (subject) has been designed and created with the intention of automating a specific task, function, or activity (object). The connection between the subject and object is one of purposeful design, where the development of the subject was aimed at streamlining or improving the efficiency of the object.

Predicate-are_generated_by.label: are generated by
Predicate-are_generated_by.description: Indicates that a subject's properties or characteristics (the motivations of the toolkit) originate from or have their basis in an object (the NER results). The predicate 'are generated by' suggests a causal relationship between the two entities, implying that the subject's attributes are derived or influenced by the object.

Predicate-is.label: is
Predicate-is.description: Indicates a state of being or identity between the subject and object. It establishes an equivalence relationship between two entities, suggesting that they share a common characteristic, property, or essence.

Predicate-use.label: use
Predicate-use.description: To employ or utilize something for a specific purpose or function. The predicate 'use' indicates that the subject (in this case, the NER results) is being put to work with the object (the NER models), likely in order to achieve some desired outcome.

Predicate-enable.label: enable
Predicate-enable.description: The predicate 'enable' indicates that the subject has the capability or authority to facilitate or make possible the occurrence of the object, which represents a state, ability, or condition. In general, it suggests that the subject's presence, action, or existence enables the object to happen or exist.

Predicate-is_processed_by.label: is processed by
Predicate-is_processed_by.description: The predicate 'is processed by' indicates a relationship between an entity (the subject) and another entity or system that performs some processing or transformation on it, resulting in a modified form of the original. This connection highlights the role of the object as a processor or agent responsible for transforming the subject into its current state.

Predicate-was_developed_to.label: was developed to
Predicate-was_developed_to.description: The predicate 'was developed to' indicates a purpose or intention behind an action or process. It suggests that something (the subject) has been created or designed with a specific goal in mind, which is described by the object.

Predicate-are_processed_by.label: are processed by
Predicate-are_processed_by.description: The predicate 'are processed by' indicates a relationship of agency or processing between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject (in this case, each processed source document) undergoes some kind of transformation, analysis, or manipulation performed by the object (the NER models). The phrase implies a causal connection between the two entities, where the object's actions have an impact on the state or characteristics of the subject.

Predicate-contains.label: contains
Predicate-contains.description: The predicate 'contains' indicates that the subject has a relationship of inclusion or possession with respect to the object. It suggests that the subject encompasses, holds, or possesses the object in some way.

Predicate-process.label: process
Predicate-process.description: To process something means to perform a series of actions or transformations on it, resulting in a changed state or form. The predicate 'process' indicates that an action has been taken on the object, which has led to its transformation into something new.

Predicate-can_be_processed_by_TNNTs_name.label: can be processed by TNNT's named entity recognition toolkit
Predicate-can_be_processed_by_TNNTs_name.description: This predicate indicates that a given input or data can be analyzed and recognized using TNNT's Named Entity Recognition (NER) toolkit. It describes the ability of the NER toolkit to process, extract, and identify specific entities such as names, locations, organizations, dates, times, etc., from various types of text-based inputs.

Predicate-to_provide.label: to provide
Predicate-to_provide.description: To provide connects a subject that possesses or has access to something (the provider) with an object that represents what is being offered or made available. This predicate implies a transfer of resources, information, or services from the subject to the object.

Predicate-The_motivations_behind_the_dev.label: The motivations behind the development of TNNT, a toolkit that automates named entity recognition (NER) analysis for unstructured information encoded in different document formats are to automate the extraction of categorised named entities from the unstructured information encoded in source documents using diverse state-of-the-art NLP tools and NER models.
Predicate-The_motivations_behind_the_dev.description: This predicate describes a causal relationship between the motivations behind the development of TNNT (a toolkit for named entity recognition analysis) and its purpose, which is to automate the extraction of categorized named entities from unstructured information in source documents using diverse NLP tools and models. The predicate highlights that the motivations driving the creation of this tool are directly linked to its intended function.

Predicate-processes.label: processes
Predicate-processes.description: The predicate 'processes' indicates a relationship between an entity (subject) and some action or transformation that is being applied to it, resulting in the creation of additional information or context. This process can involve various forms of analysis, manipulation, or interpretation, ultimately yielding new insights or representations.

Predicate-are_used_to_automate.label: are used to automate
Predicate-are_used_to_automate.description: This predicate indicates that something (the subject) serves a purpose or has an intended function in relation to automating another thing (the object). The connection between the subject and object suggests a causal relationship, where the actions or properties of the subject are directed towards achieving automation.

Predicate-generate.label: generate
Predicate-generate.description: To generate means to produce or create something new from existing information or data. The subject of the predicate generates the object by processing and transforming it in some way, often resulting in a novel output that did not previously exist.

Predicate-output.label: output
Predicate-output.description: The predicate 'output' indicates that the subject produces or generates the object. It represents a process of creation, generation, or production where the subject yields or provides the object as its result.

Predicate-automate.label: automate
Predicate-automate.description: To automate means to perform a process or task without human intervention by using pre-programmed rules, algorithms, or systems. The predicate 'automate' connects the subject (the motivations of the toolkit) with the object (the input data), indicating that the toolkit's motivations are being applied to the input data in order to execute a predetermined sequence of actions.

Predicate-are_analyzed_using.label: are analyzed using
Predicate-are_analyzed_using.description: The predicate 'are analyzed using' indicates a relationship where the subject (in this case, entities such as NER models or other analytical tools) are examined and evaluated in order to understand their properties, characteristics, or performance. The object of the sentence represents the medium, method, or framework used for analysis.

Predicate-can_be_processed_by_TNNTs_pre-.label: can be processed by TNNT's pre-processing module
Predicate-can_be_processed_by_TNNTs_pre-.description: This predicate indicates that a given entity or data can be transformed and prepared by TNNT's pre-processing module, making it suitable for further processing or analysis. The connection between the subject and object suggests that the subject requires some form of preparation to achieve the described outcome.

Predicate-processed.label: processed
Predicate-processed.description: The predicate 'processed' indicates that some action or operation has been performed on the object by the subject. It implies a transformation, manipulation, or analysis of the object's contents, resulting in a changed state or output.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject (a concept or entity) is related to another concept or entity that encompasses it, providing a higher-level categorization or classification.
